instruction: What kinds of spectral feature processing methods were used in the evaluation of soil organic matter (SOM) prediction in Southern Brazil?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods used in the evaluation of soil organic matter (SOM) prediction using near infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) in Southern Brazil were Savitzki-Golay derivative (SGD), continuum removal (CR), detrend (DET), binning (BIN), smoothing (SMO), and the standard normal variate (SNV).

instruction: What multivariate models were tested in the evaluation of soil organic matter (SOM) prediction in Southern Brazil?
Output: Multivariate models tested in the evaluation of soil organic matter (SOM) prediction in Southern Brazil included partial least squares regression (PLSR) and support vector machine (SVM).

instruction: What kinds of spectrum can be used in the evaluation of soil organic matter (SOM) prediction in Southern Brazil?
Output: The related study used nir spectrum in the evaluation of soil organic matter (SOM) prediction in Southern Brazil.

instruction: How did the different pre-processing techniques and multivariate models affect the prediction of soil organic matter (SOM) using near infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) in the related study?
Output:
In the related study, the researchers evaluated the effect of different pre-processing techniques and multivariate models on the prediction of soil organic matter (SOM) using near infrared spectroscopy (NIRS). They tested seven pre-processing techniques, including Savitzki-Golay derivative (SGD), continuum removal (CR), detrend (DET), binning (BIN), smoothing (SMO), and the standard normal variate (SNV). These pre-processing techniques were combined with four multivariate models, namely multiple linear regression (MLR), partial least squares regression (PLSR), principal component regression (PCR), support vector machine (SVM), random forest (RF), and gaussian process regression (GPR).

The performance of the predictions was evaluated using the coefficient of determination (R-2) and the root mean squared error (RMSE). The results showed that the best predictions, based on R-2, were obtained with the SVM model, followed by GPR, PLSR, MLR, PCR, and RF in decreasing order. The combination of the SVM model and SNV spectral pre-processing yielded the best prediction (R-2 = 0.70, RMSE = 0.44, RPIQ = 2.26).

instruction: Can the SVM model combined with the SNV spectral pre-processing technique be considered superior to other multivariate models in predicting soil organic matter (SOM) using near infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) in the related study?
Output: Yes, the SVM model combined with the SNV spectral pre-processing technique can be considered superior to other multivariate models in predicting soil organic matter (SOM) using near infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) in the related study. According to the results, the SVM model had the highest coefficient of determination (R-2) compared to other multivariate models, indicating better predictions. Additionally, when combined with the SNV spectral pre-processing technique, the SVM model showed the best overall performance with an R-2 value of 0.70 and a root mean squared error (RMSE) of 0.44. This suggests that the SVM model with SNV pre-processing is the most accurate and reliable in predicting SOM content using NIRS in the given study.
